title: Documentation needs indexes (function summaries)

labels.name: T-rustdoc
labels.description: Relevant to the rustdoc team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
I think that the current Rust documentation for the standard API is "too verbose". Don't get me wrong, is perfectly fine and useful like it is now. But:

- It would be better to have an "index of methods". Just compare [the java ArrayList doc](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html) to [the Rust Vec doc](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.Vec.html). In the case of the Java doc, an user looking for the method he wants is very fast because all is condensed in a little space. Nevertheless, the Rust Vec webpage is nice, but you have to scroll a lot to find the exact function you are looking for.

I think there are 2 possible solutions to this:

1) Condense the docs in a HTML "list" and show each method example and comments when you click on it.

2) Create an index on the top of the page (or another page) with one-line description of what the function does and a link to the details in the same page (down).

I'm here not just to ask for work. I can help on it if you guide me a little, even being a rust noob.
